3.heading: Mason, Andy.
3.title: Vusi Goes Back : a comic book about the history of South Africa
3.author: concept & editorial input, Rob Berold ; research & script, Dick Cloete ; script & artwork, Andy Mason ; lettering, Biddy Partridge.

publication info.publisher: Prezanian Comix in association with the Environmental Development Agency

notes: Summary: From the city of Johannesburg, Vusi goes back to visit his family in a remote area of the Transkei. His grandfather tells him about the history of his people, and Vusi learns that the way he lives today is the result of what has happened in the past. 1. South Africa

95.heading: Mason City.
95.title: "Air Mail"
95.author: Atilio Micheluzzi ; translation, Dick Hansom ; lettering, Elly De Ville
notes: Begins: "The storm's got a lot to answer for. Babel found Bella and they both find themselves deep in mud and misadventure. The authorities find the remains of one air mail pilot, and another's gone missing. And back at the hideout Ed 'Vitalis' Fletcher finds out that his girl has set off with Babel for Mason City, and Fletcher sets off after them..."

96.heading: Mason City.
96.title: "Air Mail"
96.author: Attilio Micheluzzi ; translation, Dick Hansom ; lettering, Ellie de Ville
notes: Begins: "Behind every cloud there's a silver lining- sure, and a crock of gold at the end of the rainbow. But first the rain's gotta stop. With nature conspiring to force Babel's plane down and Bella's Studey off the road, Mason City looks further away than ever. Besides, Ed Fletcher might have other plans for the man who stole his girl..."

110.heading: Le Masque.
110.title: L'Eclipse.
110.author: [No author]
notes: Published 1e année, no 1 (26 janv. 1868) - 9e année, no 400 (25 juin 1876).
Includes many issues in 2 ed., consisting of regular edition (censored), and its substitute usually designated "bis."

With this are bound various numbers of Le Philosophe, La Lune, Le Bouffon, Monde pour rire, Le Masque, Le Drolatique, and other newspapers, broadsides and hand-written materials from the period 1868-1873.
Includes caricature by André Gill and Alfred Le Petit.

139.heading: The Masquerade Mob.
139.title: "The Gang of a Thousand Faces" 8 p. in Crime Must Pay the Penalty, no. 16
139.author: [No author]
notes: Begins: "Once upon a time the mask reigned supreme in pagan rites and in the ancient theatre. Masks inspired awe and terror, frightening the beholder into paralyzed submission. Today the mask lies neglected, except as an occasional novelty. It remained for Vince Crosse and his Masquerade Mob to revive the mask in all its ancient horror, in the operations of modern gangsterdom!"
